���w�/����l���t5����i�R:���9���V���N����қ�ӆ3צӡ/v��ק_
ChatGPT said:

The data you provided appears to be the raw binary content of a PNG file. I can't directly interpret this binary dump as an image here. Could you please upload the screenshot as an image file? That way, I can view it and provide a proper interpretation.

You said:
this is how my landing page looks like, has no styling
ChatGPT said:

From your screenshot, it looks like two things are happening:

  1. Your clay background image in the header isn’t visible (the header appears solid gray).

  2. The left-hand side menu is also solid gray, overlapping the white main-content area.

Below are a few tips and code adjustments to fix these issues and get the clay background showing:

1. Make Sure the Background Image Actually Loads

Your CSS references an external Unsplash image:

css
.header-container {
  background: url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1605875200273-a63d6a51f9e1?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1600&q=80')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  ...
}

  • Check Network Access: If your environment/firewall blocks Unsplash, the image will not load, leaving you with a plain gray overlay.

  • Try a Local Image: Put a test image in your static/img/ folder and reference it with url("{{ url_for('static', filename='img/clay.jpg') }}"). Example:

    css
    .header-container {
  background: url('{{ url_for('static', filename='img/clay.jpg') }}')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  ...
}

2. Ensure No Other Background Color Is Overriding the Header

Check that you don’t have a CSS rule setting the header’s background color to gray somewhere else. For instance, if you have a .header-container { background-color: #343a40; }, it will override the background image. The code you’ve shown uses a semi-transparent overlay (rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35)) but does not set a solid background color. That’s good.

3. Remove Unwanted Gray Background on the Rest of the Page

If you’re seeing a large gray area below the header, it might come from one of these:

  • A default Bootstrap or custom background color on .container-fluid, .tennis-app-container, or body.

  • The left menu’s background (#343a40) taking up too much horizontal space.

Check that you’re not setting a gray background on .tennis-app-container or the body. For a white (or transparent) body:

css
body {
  margin: 0; 
  background-color: #fff; /* or remove for a transparent background */
}
.tennis-app-container {
  background-color: transparent; /* If you had a gray background here, remove it */
}

4. Adjust the Left Menu so It Doesn’t Overlap

You currently have:

css
.left-menu {
  position: fixed;
  top: 80px; /* right below the header */
  left: 0;
  width: 180px; /* or 250px */
  background-color: #343a40;
  ...
}
.main-content {
  margin-top: 80px;
  margin-left: 180px; /* must match .left-menu width */
  ...
}

If the left menu still overlaps your main content:

  • Make sure margin-left: 180px (or 250px) in .main-content exactly matches the .left-menu width.

  • If you see too much gray on the left, reduce .left-menu { width: 150px; } and .main-content { margin-left: 150px; }.

5. Example Complete CSS

Here’s a succinct CSS snippet you can copy-paste, which sets a white background for the main page, ensures the header is 80px tall with the clay image, and the left menu is narrower (150px). Make sure you remove any conflicting styles:

css
/* Global box-sizing (helps prevent layout issues) */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Body with white background (or remove for transparent) */
body {
  margin: 0;
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* HEADER */
.header-container {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0; left: 0; right: 0;
  height: 80px;
  background: url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1605875200273-a63d6a51f9e1?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1600&q=80')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  z-index: 1050;
  color: #fff;
}
.header-container::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0; left: 0; right: 0; bottom: 0;
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35); /* Dark overlay */
  z-index: 0;
}
.header-title {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1; 
  text-align: center;
  line-height: 80px;
  font-size: 1.8rem;
  font-weight: bold;
  margin: 0;
}

/* USER INFO (top-right) */
.user-info {
  position: absolute;
  top: 20px;
  right: 20px;
  z-index: 2;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  gap: 0.5rem;
  font-size: 1rem;
  color: #fff;
}

/* LEFT MENU */
.left-menu {
  position: fixed;
  top: 80px; /* right below header */
  left: 0;
  width: 150px;
  background-color: #343a40;
  padding: 1rem;
  overflow-y: auto;
  z-index: 1040;
}
.left-menu a {
  display: block;
  color: #fff;
  text-decoration: none;
  margin: 0.5rem 0;
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
}
.left-menu a:hover {
  background-color: #495057;
}

/* MAIN CONTENT */
.main-content {
  margin-top: 80px; /* below header */
  margin-left: 150px; /* same as .left-menu width */
  padding: 1rem;
  min-height: 100vh; /* ensures it extends down the page */
  background-color: #fff; /* or remove for transparent */
}

/* FLASH MESSAGES */
.alert {
  margin-top: 1rem;
}

/* RESPONSIVE STYLES */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .header-container {
    height: 60px;
  }
  .header-title {
    line-height: 60px;
    font-size: 1.5rem;
  }
  .left-menu {
    top: 60px;
    width: 120px;
  }
  .main-content {
    margin-top: 60px;
    margin-left: 120px;
  }
}

Key Points to Check:

  1. Link to the Correct CSS:
    In your base template, confirm you have:

    html
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ url_for('static', filename='css/style.css') }}?v=2">

    (Adding ?v=2 forces the browser to load the updated file.)

  2. Hard Refresh:
    Press Ctrl+Shift+R (Windows) or Cmd+Shift+R (Mac) to clear the cache.

  3. Network Access:
    If your environment blocks external images (like from Unsplash), host the image locally in your static/img/ folder, then reference it as:

    css
    background: url('{{ url_for('static', filename='img/clay.jpg') }}')
            no-repeat center center/cover;

Once these steps are done, your landing page should have a shorter 80px header showing the clay background (with a dark overlay), a narrower left menu (150px), and a white main content area starting exactly where the left menu ends.

You said:
give me entire code so I can copy paste
ChatGPT said:

Below is the complete code for your landing page with the adjusted header and left menu so that the main content starts immediately after the menu. You can copy and paste these three files into your project.

1. base.html

Place this file in your templates folder.

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Tennis App - {% block title %}{% endblock %}</title>
  <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.3.0/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/font-awesome/6.0.0/css/all.min.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ url_for('static', filename='css/style.css') }}?v=2">
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container-fluid tennis-app-container">
    {# Render flash messages only if hide_flashes is not set or is false #}
    {% if not hide_flashes %}
      {% with messages = get_flashed_messages(with_categories=true) %}
        {% if messages %}
          {% for category, message in messages %}
            <div class="alert alert-{{ category }} alert-dismissible fade show" role="alert">
              {{ message }}
              <button type="button" class="btn-close" data-bs-dismiss="alert" aria-label="Close"></button>
            </div>
          {% endfor %}
        {% endif %}
      {% endwith %}
    {% endif %}
    
    {% block content %}{% endblock %}
  </div>
  
  <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.3.0/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"></script>
  <script>
    // Auto-hide flash messages after 4 seconds
    window.setTimeout(function() {
      var alerts = document.querySelectorAll('.alert');
      alerts.forEach(function(alert) {
        alert.style.transition = 'opacity 0.5s ease-out';
        alert.style.opacity = '0';
        setTimeout(function() {
          alert.remove();
        }, 500);
      });
    }, 4000);
  </script>
</body>
</html>

2. landing_page.html

Place this file also in your templates folder. This page uses the base layout and contains the header, left menu, and main content.

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Landing Page{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<!-- Header with clay court background -->
<div class="header-container">
  <div class="header-title">Sebastian Championship 2025</div>
  <div class="user-info">
    <span>Welcome, <strong><a href="/profile" style="color: #fff; text-decoration: underline;">tomislav.markac</a></strong></span>
    <a href="/logout" class="logout-btn">Logout</a>
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Left-hand side menu -->
<div class="left-menu">
  <a href="#">Rezultati</a>
  <a href="#">Najave</a>
  <a href="#">Dodaj rezultat</a>
  <a href="#">Najavi meč</a>
  <a href="#">Traži</a>
  <a href="#">Informacije</a>
  <a href="#">Kontakt</a>
</div>

<!-- Main content area -->
<div class="main-content">
  <h2>Main Landing Content</h2>
  <p>This is where your landing page content goes.</p>
  <!-- Table with six columns and 10 empty rows -->
  <div class="table-responsive">
    <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
      <thead>
        <tr>
          <th>Igrač</th>
          <th>Odigrano</th>
          <th>Pobjede</th>
          <th>Setovi</th>
          <th>Gemovi</th>
          <th>Bodovi</th>
        </tr>
      </thead>
      <tbody>
        {% for i in range(10) %}
        <tr>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
        {% endfor %}
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

3. style.css

Place this file in your static/css folder.

css
/* Global box-sizing to include padding in width calculations */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Body with white background */
body {
  margin: 0;
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== HEADER STYLES ===== */
.header-container {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  height: 80px; /* Reduced header height */
  background: url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1605875200273-a63d6a51f9e1?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1600&q=80')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  z-index: 1050;
  color: #fff;
}
.header-container::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35);
  z-index: 0;
}
.header-title {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  text-align: center;
  line-height: 80px; /* Match header height */
  font-size: 1.8rem;
  font-weight: bold;
  margin: 0;
}

/* ===== USER INFO ===== */
.user-info {
  position: absolute;
  top: 20px;
  right: 20px;
  z-index: 2;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  gap: 0.5rem;
  font-size: 1rem;
  color: #fff;
}

/* ===== LEFT-HAND SIDE MENU ===== */
.left-menu {
  position: fixed;
  top: 80px; /* Starts just below the header */
  left: 0;
  width: 150px; /* Adjusted menu width */
  background-color: #343a40;
  padding: 1rem;
  overflow-y: auto;
  z-index: 1040;
}
.left-menu a {
  display: block;
  color: #fff;
  text-decoration: none;
  margin: 0.5rem 0;
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
}
.left-menu a:hover {
  background-color: #495057;
}

/* ===== MAIN CONTENT ===== */
.main-content {
  margin-top: 80px;  /* Space below header */
  margin-left: 150px; /* Exactly the width of the left menu */
  padding: 1rem;
  min-height: 100vh; /* Ensure main content extends full height */
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== FLASH MESSAGES ===== */
.alert {
  margin-top: 1rem;
}

/* ===== RESPONSIVE STYLES ===== */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .header-container {
    height: 60px;
  }
  .header-title {
    line-height: 60px;
    font-size: 1.5rem;
  }
  .left-menu {
    top: 60px;
    width: 120px;
  }
  .main-content {
    margin-top: 60px;
    margin-left: 120px;
  }
}

Final Steps

  1. Clear Your Cache:
    If you don’t see these changes immediately, try a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R or Cmd+Shift+R) or open in an incognito window.

  2. Verify File Paths:
    Make sure that your base.html links to static/css/style.css (with the version query string if needed).

This complete code should now display:

  • An 80px-high header with your clay background and dark overlay.

  • A 150px-wide left-hand side menu that does not overlap your main content.

  • A main content area starting right after the left menu.

Let me know if you need any further assistance!

Below is the updated code for your CSS and base template with the logout button restored to its previous styling.

Updated CSS (static/css/style.css)

Make sure to add (or update) the following logout button rules in your CSS file:

css
/* Global box-sizing to include padding in width calculations */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Body with white background */
body {
  margin: 0;
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== HEADER STYLES ===== */
.header-container {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  height: 80px; /* Reduced header height */
  background: url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1605875200273-a63d6a51f9e1?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1600&q=80')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  z-index: 1050;
  color: #fff;
}
.header-container::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35);
  z-index: 0;
}
.header-title {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  text-align: center;
  line-height: 80px; /* Match header height */
  font-size: 1.8rem;
  font-weight: bold;
  margin: 0;
}

.user-info {
  position: absolute;
  top: 20px;

  z-index: 2;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;

  font-size: 1rem;
  color: #fff;

.logout-btn {

  border-radius: 5px;
  cursor: pointer;
  text-decoration: none;

}

  background-color: #c82333;
}

  position: fixed;
  top: 80px; /* Starts just below the header */
  left: 0;
  width: 150px; /* Adjusted menu width */
  background-color: #343a40;
  padding: 1rem;
  overflow-y: auto;
  z-index: 1040;
}
.left-menu a {
  display: block;
  color: #fff;
  text-decoration: none;
  margin: 0.5rem 0;
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
}
.left-menu a:hover {
  background-color: #495057;
}

/* ===== MAIN CONTENT ===== */
.main-content {
  margin-top: 80px;  /* Space below header */
  margin-left: 150px; /* Exactly the width of the left menu */
  padding: 1rem;
  min-height: 100vh; /* Ensure main content extends full height */
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== FLASH MESSAGES ===== */
.alert {
  margin-top: 1rem;
}

/* ===== RESPONSIVE STYLES ===== */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .header-container {
    height: 60px;
  }
  .header-title {
    line-height: 60px;
    font-size: 1.5rem;
  }
  .left-menu {
    top: 60px;
    width: 120px;
  }
  .main-content {
    margin-top: 60px;
    margin-left: 120px;
  }
}

Updated Base Template (templates/base.html)

Ensure your logout button in the base template remains an <a> element with the class logout-btn:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Tennis App - {% block title %}{% endblock %}</title>
  <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.3.0/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/font-awesome/6.0.0/css/all.min.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ url_for('static', filename='css/style.css') }}?v=2">
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container-fluid tennis-app-container">
    {# Render flash messages only if hide_flashes is not set or is false #}
    {% if not hide_flashes %}
      {% with messages = get_flashed_messages(with_categories=true) %}
        {% if messages %}
          {% for category, message in messages %}
            <div class="alert alert-{{ category }} alert-dismissible fade show" role="alert">
              {{ message }}
              <button type="button" class="btn-close" data-bs-dismiss="alert" aria-label="Close"></button>
            </div>
          {% endfor %}
        {% endif %}
      {% endwith %}
    {% endif %}
    
    {% block content %}{% endblock %}
  </div>
  
  <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.3.0/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"></script>
  <script>
    // Auto-hide flash messages after 4 seconds
    window.setTimeout(function() {
      var alerts = document.querySelectorAll('.alert');
      alerts.forEach(function(alert) {
        alert.style.transition = 'opacity 0.5s ease-out';
        alert.style.opacity = '0';
        setTimeout(function() {
          alert.remove();
        }, 500);
      });
    }, 4000);
  </script>
</body>
</html>

Final Notes

  • Hard Refresh:
    After updating these files, do a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R / Cmd+Shift+R) or clear your browser cache to ensure the new CSS is loaded.

  • Link Verification:
    Make sure your base template correctly references the CSS file.

This should restore your logout button styling to what it was before. Let me know if you need any further adjustments!

You said:
I would like to create roles for this projects where Admins would be able to see all screens and elements while regular user not. How do I define this roles and how do I restrict some content for the regular user
ChatGPT said:

You can implement role-based access control (RBAC) in your Flask application by:

  1. Adding a Role Field to Your User Model:
    Modify your user model to include a role (for example, 'admin' or 'user'). This field can have a default value (like 'user').

  2. Storing the Role in the Session or Using Flask-Login:
    When a user logs in, store their role (or use Flask-Login's current_user, if you choose to use that extension). This way, you can check the user’s role on protected endpoints or within templates.

  3. Creating a Decorator for Admin-Only Routes:
    You can create a custom decorator (e.g., admin_required) to wrap routes that should only be accessible to admins.

  4. Using Conditional Logic in Templates:
    In your templates, you can use Jinja conditionals to display (or hide) certain elements depending on the user’s role.

Below is an example of how to modify your code to incorporate these ideas.

1. Update the User Model

Add a role column in your User model. In your app.py:

python
# Define the User model including a role field
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')  # 'admin' or 'user'

    def __repr__(self):
        return f'<User {self.username}>'

Note:
When you update your model, you might need to recreate your database or use a migration tool like Flask-Migrate if you're already in production.

2. Update the Login Route to Store the Role

When the user logs in, store their role in the session so you can use it later:

python
@app.route('/login', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def login():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        username = request.form['username']
        password = request.form['password']
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=username, password=password).first()
        if user:
            session['username'] = user.username
            session['email'] = user.email
            session['role'] = user.role  # Store the user's role
            flash('Login successful!', 'success')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        else:
            flash('Invalid username or password', 'danger')
    return render_template('login.html')

3. Create an Admin-Only Decorator

Define a decorator that checks if the current user is an admin:

python
from functools import wraps

def admin_required(f):
    @wraps(f)
    def decorated_function(*args, **kwargs):
        if 'role' not in session or session['role'] != 'admin':
            flash('Access denied: Admins only', 'danger')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        return f(*args, **kwargs)
    return decorated_function

Then, for any route that should be admin-only, use the decorator:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    # Only accessible by admin users
    return render_template('admin_dashboard.html')

4. Restrict Content in Templates Using Conditional Logic

In your templates (for example, in base.html or a specific page), you can check the role and display content conditionally:

html
{% if session.get('role') == 'admin' %}
  <!-- Content only visible to admins -->
  <a href="{{ url_for('admin_dashboard') }}">Admin Dashboard</a>
{% endif %}

This way, if the session role is not 'admin', the admin-specific link (or any other admin-only content) will not be shown.

Summary

  • Define the Role:
    Add a role field to your User model.

  • Store and Check the Role:
    Save the role in the session when a user logs in and check it using a custom decorator for routes and Jinja conditionals in templates.

  • Protect Routes:
    Use the admin_required decorator on any endpoint that should only be accessed by admins.

This approach gives you fine-grained control over who can access what parts of your application, and it allows you to show or hide content based on user roles. Let me know if you need more details or further adjustments!

You said:
where do Ipaste code in step 3
ChatGPT said:

You can paste the admin decorator code directly into your main app file (e.g., app.py) near the top—after your imports but before your route definitions. For example:

python
from flask import Flask, render_template, request, redirect, url_for, flash, session
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from functools import wraps

app = Flask(__name__)
app.secret_key = 'your_secret_key_here'  # Change this for production

# Configure SQLAlchemy
app.config['SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI'] = 'sqlite:///users.db'
app.config['SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS'] = False
db = SQLAlchemy(app)

# Define your User model here (including the 'role' field)
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')  # default role

    def __repr__(self):
        return f'<User {self.username}>'

# --- Step 3: Admin-Only Decorator ---
def admin_required(f):
    @wraps(f)
    def decorated_function(*args, **kwargs):
        if 'role' not in session or session['role'] != 'admin':
            flash('Access denied: Admins only', 'danger')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        return f(*args, **kwargs)
    return decorated_function

# Then define your routes here...

This way, the admin_required decorator is available for use on any route you want to restrict to admins. If you prefer better organization, you could create a separate file (e.g., decorators.py) with that code and import it into app.py using:

python
from decorators import admin_required

Let me know if you need more help with this!

You said:
if @app.route('/admin-dashboard') @admin_required def admin_dashboard(): # Only accessible by admin users return render_template('admin_dashboard.html') if I want to apply this to this route; # Logout route @app.route('/logout', methods=['GET', 'POST']) def logout(): session.clear() flash('You have been logged out', 'info') return redirect(url_for('login')) how would the code work
ChatGPT said:

If you add the @admin_required decorator to the logout route, then only users with the role "admin" (as stored in the session) will be allowed to access that route. For example:

python
@app.route('/logout', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
@admin_required
def logout():
    session.clear()
    flash('You have been logged out', 'info')
    return redirect(url_for('login'))

In this code, before the logout function is executed, the admin_required decorator checks whether the session contains a role set to "admin". If it does not, it will flash an "Access denied: Admins only" message and redirect the user to the home page. This means that a regular user would be prevented from logging out via this route.

Note:
Usually, you wouldn't restrict the logout functionality to admin users because every user should be able to log out. The admin_required decorator is more typically applied to pages that should be accessible only to administrators, like an admin dashboard. If your intention is to restrict certain routes to admin users while keeping logout accessible to everyone, simply do not decorate the logout route with @admin_required.

You said:
so basically I am adding only this to the routes that should be visible only to admins: @admin_required
ChatGPT said:

Yes, exactly. For any route that should be restricted to admins only, simply add the @admin_required decorator above the route. This ensures that when a request is made to that endpoint, the decorator checks the user's role (stored in the session) and only allows access if the role is 'admin'.

For example, for an admin dashboard route:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    # Only accessible by admin users
    return render_template('admin_dashboard.html')

This decorator isn't meant for routes like logout, which should be accessible to all users. You only apply @admin_required to those routes you want to restrict exclusively to administrators.

You said:
OK, lets make an admin dashboard. I presume it will require a new let's say admin.html. There admin should be able to pick from all registrated users the ones that will play a particular tournament. Then have them displayed in some table: -Their first name and last name together in a form of alink when clicked it should take the admint to that players profile page -year of birth - total matches played -win -loss -win % which is calculated as win/total matches played - button with the functionality to Add Player(logic will be implemented later) -button with the functionality to Remove Player(logic will be implemented later) - button with the functionality to Freeze Player(logic will be implemented later) Finnaly add option to the left hand menu in the landing_page.html named Admin and it should only be visible to Adnin. make it standout from the other options in the menu. When clicked on that option it should redirect the Admin to the admin.html. Return all code so I can copy paste
ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete example showing how you can add an admin dashboard that meets your requirements. In this example:

  • We add a new template file (admin.html) where the admin can view a table of all registered users.

  • The table shows each player’s full name (as a link that directs to their profile), year of birth, and columns for total matches played, wins, losses, and win % (using dummy values if not stored).

  • Action buttons (“Add Player”, “Remove Player”, “Freeze Player”) are shown for each row (the underlying logic can be implemented later).

  • The left-hand side menu in your landing page now includes an “Admin” option that is visible only when the logged‐in user’s role is "admin". This link is styled to stand out.

You can copy and paste the following code into your project.

1. app.py

Make sure you update your routes to include an admin dashboard route and a profile route that accepts a username parameter for admin use.

python
from flask import Flask, render_template, request, redirect, url_for, flash, session
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from functools import wraps

app = Flask(__name__)
app.secret_key = 'your_secret_key_here'  # Change for production

# Configure SQLAlchemy to use an SQLite database called users.db
app.config['SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI'] = 'sqlite:///users.db'
app.config['SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS'] = False

db = SQLAlchemy(app)

# Define the User model (including a role field)
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')  # 'admin' or 'user'

    def __repr__(self):
        return f'<User {self.username}>'

# --- Admin-Only Decorator ---
def admin_required(f):
    @wraps(f)
    def decorated_function(*args, **kwargs):
        if 'role' not in session or session['role'] != 'admin':
            flash('Access denied: Admins only', 'danger')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        return f(*args, **kwargs)
    return decorated_function

# Registration route (simplified; assumes form collects all necessary fields)
@app.route('/register', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def register():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        first_name = request.form['first_name']
        last_name = request.form['last_name']
        email = request.form['email']
        phone = request.form['phone']
        birth_year = request.form['birth_year']
        handedness = request.form['handedness']
        username = request.form['username']
        password = request.form['password']

        if User.query.filter_by(username=username).first():
            flash('Username already exists', 'danger')
        else:
            new_user = User(
                first_name=first_name,
                last_name=last_name,
                email=email,
                phone=phone,
                birth_year=birth_year,
                handedness=handedness,
                username=username,
                password=password
            )
            db.session.add(new_user)
            db.session.commit()
            flash('Registration successful! Please login.', 'success')
            return redirect(url_for('login'))
    return render_template('register.html')

# Login route (stores role in session)
@app.route('/login', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def login():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        username = request.form['username']
        password = request.form['password']
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=username, password=password).first()
        if user:
            session['username'] = user.username
            session['email'] = user.email
            session['role'] = user.role  # Store role
            flash('Login successful!', 'success')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        else:
            flash('Invalid username or password', 'danger')
    return render_template('login.html')

# Forgot Password route
@app.route('/forgot-password', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def forgot_password():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        email = request.form['email']
        flash('If an account exists with that email, a password reset link has been sent.', 'info')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))
    return render_template('forgot_password.html')

# Home route (landing page)
@app.route('/')
def home():
    if 'username' in session:
        return render_template('landing_page.html')
    return redirect(url_for('login'))

# Profile route for logged-in user
@app.route('/profile')
def profile():
    if 'username' not in session:
        flash('Please login to view your profile', 'warning')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=session['username']).first()
    if user:
        return render_template('profile_page.html', user=user)
    else:
        flash('User not found', 'danger')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))

# Profile route for admin viewing any user's profile
@app.route('/profile/<username>')
def profile_by_username(username):
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=username).first()
    if user:
        return render_template('profile_page.html', user=user)
    else:
        flash('User not found', 'danger')
        return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

# Update profile route
@app.route('/update-profile', methods=['POST'])
def update_profile():
    if 'username' not in session:
        flash('Please login to update your profile', 'warning')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=session['username']).first()
    if user:
        user.first_name = request.form.get('first_name', user.first_name)
        user.last_name = request.form.get('last_name', user.last_name)
        user.email = request.form.get('email', user.email)
        user.phone = request.form.get('phone', user.phone)
        user.birth_year = request.form.get('birth_year', user.birth_year)
        user.handedness = request.form.get('handedness', user.handedness)
        db.session.commit()
        flash('Profile updated successfully!', 'success')
    else:
        flash('User not found', 'danger')
    return redirect(url_for('profile'))

# Admin dashboard route (only for admins)
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    users = User.query.all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=users)

# Logout route (accessible to everyone)
@app.route('/logout', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def logout():
    session.clear()
    flash('You have been logged out', 'info')
    return redirect(url_for('login'))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    with app.app_context():
        db.create_all()
    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000, debug=True)

2. admin.html

Place this file in your templates folder. It shows a table of all registered users with the required columns and action buttons.

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5">
  <h2>Admin Dashboard</h2>
  <p>Select players for the tournament:</p>
  <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
    <thead>
      <tr>
        <th>Player Name</th>
        <th>Year of Birth</th>
        <th>Total Matches</th>
        <th>Win</th>
        <th>Loss</th>
        <th>Win %</th>
        <th>Actions</th>
      </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
      {% for user in users %}
      <tr>
        <td>
          <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
            {{ user.first_name }} {{ user.last_name }}
          </a>
        </td>
        <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
        <td>0</td>
        <td>0</td>
        <td>0</td>
        <td>0%</td>
        <td>
          <button class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</button>
          <button class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Remove Player</button>
          <button class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Freeze Player</button>
        </td>
      </tr>
      {% endfor %}
    </tbody>
  </table>
</div>
{% endblock %}

Note: Since your current user model doesn’t track match statistics, the table displays 0’s for “Total Matches,” “Win,” “Loss,” and “Win %.” You can later extend your model and logic to update these fields.

3. landing_page.html

Update your landing page to include an “Admin” option in the left-hand side menu that appears only for admins.

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Landing Page{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<!-- Header with clay court background -->
<div class="header-container">
  <div class="header-title">Sebastian Championship 2025</div>
  <div class="user-info">
    <span>Welcome, <strong><a href="/profile" style="color: #fff; text-decoration: underline;">tomislav.markac</a></strong></span>
    <a href="/logout" class="logout-btn">Logout</a>
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Left-hand side menu -->
<div class="left-menu">
  <a href="#">Rezultati</a>
  <a href="#">Najave</a>
  <a href="#">Dodaj rezultat</a>
  <a href="#">Najavi meč</a>
  <a href="#">Traži</a>
  <a href="#">Informacije</a>
  <a href="#">Kontakt</a>
  {% if session.get('role') == 'admin' %}
    <a href="{{ url_for('admin_dashboard') }}" class="admin-menu">Admin</a>
  {% endif %}
</div>

<!-- Main content area -->
<div class="main-content">
  <h2>Main Landing Content</h2>
  <p>This is where your landing page content goes.</p>
  <!-- Table with six columns and 10 empty rows -->
  <div class="table-responsive">
    <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
      <thead>
        <tr>
          <th>Igrač</th>
          <th>Odigrano</th>
          <th>Pobjede</th>
          <th>Setovi</th>
          <th>Gemovi</th>
          <th>Bodovi</th>
        </tr>
      </thead>
      <tbody>
        {% for i in range(10) %}
        <tr>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
        {% endfor %}
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

4. style.css

Place this file in your static/css folder. It includes styles for the header, left menu, main content, and now a distinct style for the admin menu option.

css
/* Global box-sizing */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Body with white background */
body {
  margin: 0;
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== HEADER STYLES ===== */
.header-container {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  height: 80px; /* Reduced header height */
  background: url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1605875200273-a63d6a51f9e1?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1600&q=80')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  z-index: 1050;
  color: #fff;
}
.header-container::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35);
  z-index: 0;
}
.header-title {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  text-align: center;
  line-height: 80px; /* Match header height */
  font-size: 1.8rem;
  font-weight: bold;
  margin: 0;
}

/* ===== USER INFO ===== */
.user-info {
  position: absolute;
  top: 20px;
  right: 20px;
  z-index: 2;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  gap: 0.5rem;
  font-size: 1rem;
  color: #fff;
}

/* ===== LOGOUT BUTTON STYLING ===== */
.logout-btn {
  background-color: #dc3545;
  border: none;
  padding: 0.5rem 1rem;
  color: #fff;
  border-radius: 5px;
  cursor: pointer;
  text-decoration: none;
  font-size: 1rem;
}
.logout-btn:hover {
  background-color: #c82333;
}

/* ===== LEFT-HAND SIDE MENU ===== */
.left-menu {
  position: fixed;
  top: 80px; /* Starts just below the header */
  left: 0;
  width: 150px; /* Adjusted menu width */
  background-color: #343a40;
  padding: 1rem;
  overflow-y: auto;
  z-index: 1040;
}
.left-menu a {
  display: block;
  color: #fff;
  text-decoration: none;
  margin: 0.5rem 0;
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
}
.left-menu a:hover {
  background-color: #495057;
}

/* ===== ADMIN MENU OPTION ===== */
.admin-menu {
  font-weight: bold;
  color: #fff;
  background-color: #ff9800; /* Distinct color for admin */
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
  margin-top: 1rem;
  display: block;
  text-decoration: none;
}
.admin-menu:hover {
  background-color: #e68900;
}

/* ===== MAIN CONTENT ===== */
.main-content {
  margin-top: 80px;  /* Space below header */
  margin-left: 150px; /* Exactly the width of the left menu */
  padding: 1rem;
  min-height: 100vh; /* Ensure main content extends full height */
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== FLASH MESSAGES ===== */
.alert {
  margin-top: 1rem;
}

/* ===== RESPONSIVE STYLES ===== */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .header-container {
    height: 60px;
  }
  .header-title {
    line-height: 60px;
    font-size: 1.5rem;
  }
  .left-menu {
    top: 60px;
    width: 120px;
  }
  .main-content {
    margin-top: 60px;
    margin-left: 120px;
  }
}

Final Steps

  1. Clear Your Cache:
    After copying the new code, perform a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R / Cmd+Shift+R) or clear your browser cache.

  2. Test:
    Log in as an admin (i.e. a user with role set to "admin") and verify that:

    • The left menu now shows an “Admin” link in a distinct style.

    • Clicking “Admin” directs you to the admin dashboard where you see the table of users.

    • Each user’s name is a link that takes you to that player’s profile page.

This complete code should let you copy and paste into your project and meet the requirements for an admin dashboard with role-based content. Let me know if you need any further adjustments!

You said:
how do i login as Admin?
ChatGPT said:

By default, the registration form creates users with the role set to "user". To log in as an admin, you need to have a user with the role "admin". Here are a few options:

  1. Manually Create an Admin User:
    You can open a Python shell with your Flask app context and manually create a user with the role set to "admin". For example:

    python
    from app import db, User
admin = User(
    first_name="Admin",
    last_name="User",
    username="admin",
    password="adminpassword",  # In production, use hashed passwords
    email="admin@example.com",
    phone="1234567890",
    birth_year=1980,
    handedness="right",
    role="admin"
)
db.session.add(admin)
db.session.commit()

    Then, log in using the credentials for this admin user.

  2. Modify an Existing User's Role:
    If you already have a registered user, you can manually change their role in your database to "admin". For instance, if you’re using SQLite, you could use an SQLite browser to open users.db and update the role field for that user.

  3. Temporarily Allow Admin Selection on Registration (For Testing Only):
    You could modify your registration form to let you choose a role, but be very careful with this approach in production. For testing, you might add a hidden field or a dropdown to set the role to "admin".

Once you have a user with role="admin", log in using that user's credentials and the session will store the role as "admin". Then, any routes or content protected with the @admin_required decorator or checked with session.get('role') == 'admin' will be accessible.

You said:
OK show me how to do step 2 in visual studio code
ChatGPT said:

Here's how you can modify an existing user's role to "admin" using Visual Studio Code:

  1. Open the Terminal in VS Code:
    In VS Code, open the integrated terminal (you can use the shortcut Ctrl+` on Windows/Linux or Cmd+` on macOS).

  2. Activate Your Virtual Environment:
    If you're using a virtual environment, make sure it's activated. For example, on Windows:

    bash
    .\venv\Scripts\activate

    Or on macOS/Linux:

    bash
    source venv/bin/activate

  3. Open a Python Shell with Your App Context:
    In the terminal, start a Python shell by typing:

    bash
    python

    Then, import your Flask app and models. For example, if your main file is named app.py, type:

    python
    from app import db, User, app

  4. Push the App Context:
    Before interacting with the database, push the app context:

    python
    app.app_context().push()

  5. Find the User and Update Their Role:
    Query for the user you want to change (for example, with username "john") and update their role:

    python
    user = User.query.filter_by(username="john").first()
if user:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")
else:
    print("User not found.")

  6. Exit the Python Shell:
    Type exit() or press Ctrl+D to exit the shell.

Now the user "john" will have the role "admin", and when you log in with that user, you'll have admin privileges.

This process is done directly from VS Code's terminal using your project's Python environment. Let me know if you need further details or assistance!

You said:
in step 5 my username is tomislav.markac how should the query look like
ChatGPT said:

In that case, your query should look like this:

python
user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
if user:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")
else:
    print("User not found.")

This will update the role of the user with the username "tomislav.markac" to "admin".

You said:
Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> NameError: name 'user' is not defined. Did you mean: 'User'?
ChatGPT said:

That error indicates that the variable user hasn't been defined before you try to use it. Please make sure you run the full code snippet step by step in your Python shell. For example, try the following commands one by one:

python
# Import necessary items from your app
from app import db, User, app

# Push the application context so we can work with the database
app.app_context().push()

# Query for the user with username "tomislav.markac" and assign it to the variable 'user'
user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()

# Check if the user exists, then update their role
if user:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")
else:
    print("User not found.")

Make sure you type (or paste) each of these commands into your Python shell. The error you received suggests that perhaps you tried to use user before assigning it. Let me know if you need any more help!

self.dialect.do_execute( File "C:\Users\tmarkac\Python_projects\Tennis_app\venv\Lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\engine\default.py", line 945, in do_execute cursor.execute(statement, parameters) sqlalchemy.exc.OperationalError: (sqlite3.OperationalError) no such column: user.role [SQL: SELECT user.id AS user_id, user.first_name AS user_first_name, user.last_name AS user_last_name, user.username AS user_username, user.password AS user_password, user.eemail AS user_email, user.phone AS user_phone, user.birth_year AS user_birth_year, user.handedness AS user_handedness, user.role AS user_role FROM user WHERE user.username = ? LIMIT ? OFFSET ?] [parameters: ('tomislav.markac', 1, 0)] (Background on this error at: https://sqlalche.me/e/20/e3q8) >>>
ChatGPT said:

This error indicates that your database doesn't have the new "role" column even though you've updated your User model. When you modify your model (for example, by adding a new field), the existing SQLite database won't automatically update its schema.

You have a few options:

  1. Delete the Existing Database (for development/testing):
    If you’re in development, you can delete your current users.db file and then re-run your application. The call to db.create_all() will create a new database with the updated schema including the role column.

  2. Use a Migration Tool (e.g., Flask-Migrate):
    For a production or persistent environment, use a migration tool like Flask-Migrate to apply schema changes without losing existing data.

For a quick fix in development, simply close your app, delete users.db, and then run your app again.

Let me know if you need more help with setting up migrations or if you have further questions!

You said:
what do I need to do to delete the db and recreate it
ChatGPT said:

If you're in development and it's safe to lose your existing data, you can delete your current SQLite database file (e.g., users.db) and then let your app recreate it on startup. Here’s how you can do it:

  1. Close Your Application:
    Make sure your Flask app is not running.

  2. Locate and Delete the Database File:
    In your project directory (e.g., in Visual Studio Code’s Explorer pane), find the users.db file (usually in the root of your project if you’re using sqlite:///users.db) and delete it.

  3. Re-run Your Application:
    When you start your app again, the code in your if __name__ == '__main__': block will call:

    python
    with app.app_context():
    db.create_all()

    This command creates all the tables defined in your models, including the new role column in the User table.

  4. Verify the Changes:
    Once your app is running again, you can check your database (using an SQLite viewer or the command line) to confirm that the role column is present in the User table.

This process will delete the old database and create a new one with your updated model schema. Let me know if you need further assistance!

You said:
I have set tomislav.markac as admin but I cant see the elements that should be only visible to admin
ChatGPT said:

There are a few possible reasons why the admin-only elements aren't showing up. Here are some steps to troubleshoot and fix the issue:

  1. Verify Session Data:
    Make sure that when you log in, your session actually stores the role. You can temporarily add this line in your base template (or landing page) to see what role is in the session:

    html
    <p>Role: {{ session.get('role') }}</p>

    This will help you verify that session['role'] is set to "admin" as expected.

  2. Case Sensitivity:
    Ensure that the role in the database is exactly "admin" (all lowercase) and that your conditional check in the template is:

    html
    {% if session.get('role') == 'admin' %}
  <a href="{{ url_for('admin_dashboard') }}" class="admin-menu">Admin</a>
{% endif %}

  3. Clear Cache and Relogin:
    If you recently updated the role, make sure to log out and log back in so that the session is updated with the correct role.

  4. Template Condition:
    Double-check that the condition is in the correct place in your landing page template and that there are no typos. For example:

    html
    <!-- Left-hand side menu -->
<div class="left-menu">
  <a href="#">Rezultati</a>
  <a href="#">Najave</a>
  <a href="#">Dodaj rezultat</a>
  <a href="#">Najavi meč</a>
  <a href="#">Traži</a>
  <a href="#">Informacije</a>
  <a href="#">Kontakt</a>
  {% if session.get('role') == 'admin' %}
    <a href="{{ url_for('admin_dashboard') }}" class="admin-menu">Admin</a>
  {% endif %}
</div>

  5. Re-check the Login Route:
    Confirm that your login route stores the role in the session. For example:

    python
    @app.route('/login', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def login():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        username = request.form['username']
        password = request.form['password']
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=username, password=password).first()
        if user:
            session['username'] = user.username
            session['email'] = user.email
            session['role'] = user.role  # Ensure this is set!
            flash('Login successful!', 'success')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        else:
            flash('Invalid username or password', 'danger')
    return render_template('login.html')

By verifying these points, you should be able to see the admin-only elements when you log in as an admin. Let me know if you need any more help!

You said:
<p>Role: {{ session.get('role') }}</p> where in the base file do i put this
ChatGPT said:

You can insert that debugging line anywhere within the <body> where it’s visible. A good place might be just below the flash messages and before your main content block. For example, update your base.html like this:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Tennis App - {% block title %}{% endblock %}</title>
  <link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.3.0/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/font-awesome/6.0.0/css/all.min.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ url_for('static', filename='css/style.css') }}?v=2">
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container-fluid tennis-app-container">
    {# Render flash messages only if hide_flashes is not set or is false #}
    {% if not hide_flashes %}
      {% with messages = get_flashed_messages(with_categories=true) %}
        {% if messages %}
          {% for category, message in messages %}
            <div class="alert alert-{{ category }} alert-dismissible fade show" role="alert">
              {{ message }}
              <button type="button" class="btn-close" data-bs-dismiss="alert" aria-label="Close"></button>
            </div>
          {% endfor %}
        {% endif %}
      {% endwith %}
    {% endif %}
    
    <!-- Debug: Display role stored in session -->
    <p>Role: {{ session.get('role') }}</p>
    
    {% block content %}{% endblock %}
  </div>
  
  <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.3.0/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js"></script>
  <script>
    // Auto-hide flash messages after 4 seconds
    window.setTimeout(function() {
      var alerts = document.querySelectorAll('.alert');
      alerts.forEach(function(alert) {
        alert.style.transition = 'opacity 0.5s ease-out';
        alert.style.opacity = '0';
        setTimeout(function() {
          alert.remove();
        }, 500);
      });
    }, 4000);
  </script>
</body>
</html>

This will display the role (e.g., "admin" or "user") on every page that uses base.html. Once you've confirmed it, you can remove or comment out that line.

You said:
the problem is that the role for tomislav.markac is user not admin
ChatGPT said:

If the role for "tomislav.markac" is still "user" even though you intended it to be "admin", you'll need to update it in your database. Since you've already modified your User model to include a role field, you can update the user's role using the Python shell in VS Code.

Follow these steps:

  1. Open the Integrated Terminal in VS Code:
    Use Ctrl+` (backtick) or go to View > Terminal.

  2. Activate Your Virtual Environment:
    For example, on Windows:

    bash
    .\venv\Scripts\activate

    On macOS/Linux:

    bash
    source venv/bin/activate

  3. Start a Python Shell:
    Type:

    bash
    python

    This will open an interactive shell.

  4. Import Your App and Models and Push the App Context:
    In the Python shell, run:

    python
    from app import db, User, app
app.app_context().push()

  5. Query the User and Update Their Role:
    Now run:

    python
    user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
if user:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")
else:
    print("User not found.")

    This code queries for "tomislav.markac", updates the role to "admin", and commits the change.

  6. Exit the Shell:
    Type exit() or press Ctrl+D.

  7. Log Out and Log In Again:
    Ensure you log out and then log in again so that the session is updated with the new role.

After these steps, your debugging line <p>Role: {{ session.get('role') }}</p> should display "admin" for "tomislav.markac" and the admin-only elements should become visible. Let me know if you run into any more issues!

You said:
how do I run this in python shell: from app import db, User, app app.app_context().push()
ChatGPT said:

To run that code in the Python shell, follow these steps:

  1. Open the Terminal in Visual Studio Code:
    You can open the integrated terminal by clicking on View > Terminal or using the shortcut (usually Ctrl+`).

  2. Navigate to Your Project Directory:
    Make sure your terminal's current working directory is where your app.py file is located.

  3. Activate Your Virtual Environment (if applicable):

    • On Windows, run:

      bash
      .\venv\Scripts\activate

    • On macOS/Linux, run:

      bash
      source venv/bin/activate

  4. Start the Python Shell:
    Type:

    bash
    python

    This will open the interactive Python shell.

  5. Run the Following Code in the Python Shell:
    Copy and paste the following lines one at a time:

    python
    from app import db, User, app
app.app_context().push()

    This imports your database, your User model, and your app, then pushes the application context so you can work with your database.

  6. Now You Can Run the Update Code:
    For example, to update your user role, type:

    python
    user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
if user:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")
else:
    print("User not found.")

Once done, exit the Python shell by typing exit() or pressing Ctrl+D.

This process allows you to run your code directly in the shell using your app’s context. Let me know if you need any further help!

You said:
but when i paste in the shell do I need to click enter or something. Where do I run it
ChatGPT said:

When you're in the interactive Python shell (the REPL), you can paste each line and then press Enter after each line. Here’s a step-by-step guide:

  1. Open the Terminal in VS Code:

    • Go to View > Terminal (or use the shortcut Ctrl+`).

  2. Navigate to Your Project Directory:

    • Ensure that your terminal is in the same folder where your app.py file is located.

  3. Activate Your Virtual Environment (if needed):

    • On Windows:

      bash
      .\venv\Scripts\activate

    • On macOS/Linux:

      bash
      source venv/bin/activate

  4. Start the Python Shell:

    • Type python and press Enter. This starts the interactive shell (you should see something like >>>).

  5. Paste the Code Line by Line:

    • Now, paste each line of the following code and press Enter after each line:

      python
      from app import db, User, app
app.app_context().push()

    • You should see no errors (if everything is set up correctly).

  6. Run Your Update Code:

    • Then paste and execute:

      python
      user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
if user:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")
else:
    print("User not found.")

  7. Exit the Shell:

    • When you’re done, type exit() or press Ctrl+D.

Each time you paste a line, press Enter so that the code executes. If you have multiple lines, you can paste them one by one or paste them all at once if your shell supports multi-line paste.

Let me know if you have any more questions!

You said:
amazing, all is fine
ChatGPT said:

You said:
OK, let us continue. We will modify the admin-dashboard. On it there should be two tabs. The first one will be: - Users: basically all that we have in the current admin-dashboard should be in the Users tab. -Participatns: this tab will contain only users that have been added by the admin to participate in the championship by clicking on the Add Player button form the Users tab. This tab should have table with same layout as the one in Users, so you need to create a method when the admin clicks on Add Player it populates the table in the Participants tab with relevant info. Give me an entire code so I can copy paste
ChatGPT said:
You said:
will you return the code?
ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete example with the changes needed for an admin dashboard that has two tabs: one for all Users and one for Participants. In this example, we add a new Boolean field called participant to the User model. When the admin clicks the Add Player button in the Users tab, a route is called that sets that user’s participant field to True. The Participants tab then displays only users with participant=True. (A similar approach is used for the Remove Player button.) The Freeze Player button is included as a placeholder for functionality you can implement later.

Please copy and paste the following code into your project.

1. app.py

Make sure your file includes the updated User model with the new field and the additional routes for managing participants.

python
from flask import Flask, render_template, request, redirect, url_for, flash, session
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from functools import wraps

app = Flask(__name__)
app.secret_key = 'your_secret_key_here'  # Change for production

# Configure SQLAlchemy to use an SQLite database called users.db
app.config['SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI'] = 'sqlite:///users.db'
app.config['SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS'] = False
db = SQLAlchemy(app)

# Updated User model to include role and participant fields
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')  # 'admin' or 'user'
    participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False)  # For tournament participation

    def __repr__(self):
        return f'<User {self.username}>'

# Admin-only decorator
def admin_required(f):
    @wraps(f)
    def decorated_function(*args, **kwargs):
        if 'role' not in session or session['role'] != 'admin':
            flash('Access denied: Admins only', 'danger')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        return f(*args, **kwargs)
    return decorated_function

# Registration route (simplified)
@app.route('/register', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def register():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        first_name = request.form['first_name']
        last_name = request.form['last_name']
        email = request.form['email']
        phone = request.form['phone']
        birth_year = request.form['birth_year']
        handedness = request.form['handedness']
        username = request.form['username']
        password = request.form['password']

        if User.query.filter_by(username=username).first():
            flash('Username already exists', 'danger')
        else:
            new_user = User(
                first_name=first_name,
                last_name=last_name,
                email=email,
                phone=phone,
                birth_year=birth_year,
                handedness=handedness,
                username=username,
                password=password
            )
            db.session.add(new_user)
            db.session.commit()
            flash('Registration successful! Please login.', 'success')
            return redirect(url_for('login'))
    return render_template('register.html')

# Login route (stores role in session)
@app.route('/login', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def login():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        username = request.form['username']
        password = request.form['password']
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=username, password=password).first()
        if user:
            session['username'] = user.username
            session['email'] = user.email
            session['role'] = user.role
            flash('Login successful!', 'success')
            return redirect(url_for('home'))
        else:
            flash('Invalid username or password', 'danger')
    return render_template('login.html')

# Forgot Password route
@app.route('/forgot-password', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def forgot_password():
    if request.method == 'POST':
        email = request.form['email']
        flash('If an account exists with that email, a password reset link has been sent.', 'info')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))
    return render_template('forgot_password.html')

# Home route (landing page)
@app.route('/')
def home():
    if 'username' in session:
        return render_template('landing_page.html')
    return redirect(url_for('login'))

# Profile route for logged in user
@app.route('/profile')
def profile():
    if 'username' not in session:
        flash('Please login to view your profile', 'warning')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=session['username']).first()
    if user:
        return render_template('profile_page.html', user=user)
    else:
        flash('User not found', 'danger')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))

# Profile route for admin viewing any user's profile
@app.route('/profile/<username>')
def profile_by_username(username):
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=username).first()
    if user:
        return render_template('profile_page.html', user=user)
    else:
        flash('User not found', 'danger')
        return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

# Update profile route
@app.route('/update-profile', methods=['POST'])
def update_profile():
    if 'username' not in session:
        flash('Please login to update your profile', 'warning')
        return redirect(url_for('login'))
    user = User.query.filter_by(username=session['username']).first()
    if user:
        user.first_name = request.form.get('first_name', user.first_name)
        user.last_name = request.form.get('last_name', user.last_name)
        user.email = request.form.get('email', user.email)
        user.phone = request.form.get('phone', user.phone)
        user.birth_year = request.form.get('birth_year', user.birth_year)
        user.handedness = request.form.get('handedness', user.handedness)
        db.session.commit()
        flash('Profile updated successfully!', 'success')
    else:
        flash('User not found', 'danger')
    return redirect(url_for('profile'))

# Admin dashboard route with two tabs (Users and Participants)
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.all()
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

# Route to add a user as participant
@app.route('/add-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def add_participant(user_id):
    user = User.query.get(user_id)
    if user:
        user.participant = True
        db.session.commit()
        flash(f'{user.first_name} {user.last_name} has been added as a participant.', 'success')
    else:
        flash('User not found.', 'danger')
    return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

# Route to remove a participant
@app.route('/remove-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def remove_participant(user_id):
    user = User.query.get(user_id)
    if user:
        user.participant = False
        db.session.commit()
        flash(f'{user.first_name} {user.last_name} has been removed from participants.', 'warning')
    else:
        flash('User not found.', 'danger')
    return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

# (Optional) Freeze player route – placeholder for now
@app.route('/freeze-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def freeze_participant(user_id):
    # Placeholder logic for freezing a player; implement as needed
    flash(f'Freeze functionality not implemented yet for user id {user_id}.', 'info')
    return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

# Logout route (accessible to all users)
@app.route('/logout', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def logout():
    session.clear()
    flash('You have been logged out', 'info')
    return redirect(url_for('login'))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    with app.app_context():
        db.create_all()
    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000, debug=True)

2. admin.html

Place this file in your templates folder. This template uses Bootstrap tabs to switch between the Users and Participants views. In the Users tab, the table lists all users with action buttons. In the Participants tab, the table shows only those users marked as participants.

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5">
  <h2>Admin Dashboard</h2>

  <!-- Bootstrap tabs -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">Users</button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="participants-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#participants" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="participants" aria-selected="false">Participants</button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.first_name }} {{ user.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('add_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</a>
                {% else %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                {% endif %}
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    <!-- Participants Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in participants %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.first_name }} {{ user.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

3. Landing Page Update (landing_page.html)

Make sure the left-hand menu includes an Admin link visible only to admins. For example:

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Landing Page{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<!-- Header with clay court background -->
<div class="header-container">
  <div class="header-title">Sebastian Championship 2025</div>
  <div class="user-info">
    <span>Welcome, <strong><a href="/profile" style="color: #fff; text-decoration: underline;">tomislav.markac</a></strong></span>
    <a href="/logout" class="logout-btn">Logout</a>
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Left-hand side menu -->
<div class="left-menu">
  <a href="#">Rezultati</a>
  <a href="#">Najave</a>
  <a href="#">Dodaj rezultat</a>
  <a href="#">Najavi meč</a>
  <a href="#">Traži</a>
  <a href="#">Informacije</a>
  <a href="#">Kontakt</a>
  {% if session.get('role') == 'admin' %}
    <a href="{{ url_for('admin_dashboard') }}" class="admin-menu">Admin</a>
  {% endif %}
</div>

<!-- Main content area -->
<div class="main-content">
  <h2>Main Landing Content</h2>
  <p>This is where your landing page content goes.</p>
  <!-- Table with six columns and 10 empty rows -->
  <div class="table-responsive">
    <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
      <thead>
        <tr>
          <th>Igrač</th>
          <th>Odigrano</th>
          <th>Pobjede</th>
          <th>Setovi</th>
          <th>Gemovi</th>
          <th>Bodovi</th>
        </tr>
      </thead>
      <tbody>
        {% for i in range(10) %}
        <tr>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
          <td>&nbsp;</td>
        </tr>
        {% endfor %}
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

4. style.css

Place this file in static/css/style.css (if you haven’t updated it already). It includes styling for the admin menu link as well.

css
/* Global box-sizing */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Body with white background */
body {
  margin: 0;
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== HEADER STYLES ===== */
.header-container {
  position: fixed;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  height: 80px; /* Reduced header height */
  background: url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1605875200273-a63d6a51f9e1?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=1600&q=80')
              no-repeat center center/cover;
  z-index: 1050;
  color: #fff;
}
.header-container::before {
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.35);
  z-index: 0;
}
.header-title {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  text-align: center;
  line-height: 80px; /* Match header height */
  font-size: 1.8rem;
  font-weight: bold;
  margin: 0;
}

/* ===== USER INFO ===== */
.user-info {
  position: absolute;
  top: 20px;
  right: 20px;
  z-index: 2;
  display: flex;
  align-items: center;
  gap: 0.5rem;
  font-size: 1rem;
  color: #fff;
}

/* ===== LOGOUT BUTTON STYLING ===== */
.logout-btn {
  background-color: #dc3545;
  border: none;
  padding: 0.5rem 1rem;
  color: #fff;
  border-radius: 5px;
  cursor: pointer;
  text-decoration: none;
  font-size: 1rem;
}
.logout-btn:hover {
  background-color: #c82333;
}

/* ===== LEFT-HAND SIDE MENU ===== */
.left-menu {
  position: fixed;
  top: 80px; /* Starts just below the header */
  left: 0;
  width: 150px; /* Adjusted menu width */
  background-color: #343a40;
  padding: 1rem;
  overflow-y: auto;
  z-index: 1040;
}
.left-menu a {
  display: block;
  color: #fff;
  text-decoration: none;
  margin: 0.5rem 0;
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
}
.left-menu a:hover {
  background-color: #495057;
}

/* ===== ADMIN MENU OPTION ===== */
.admin-menu {
  font-weight: bold;
  color: #fff;
  background-color: #ff9800; /* Distinct color for admin */
  padding: 0.5rem;
  border-radius: 5px;
  margin-top: 1rem;
  display: block;
  text-decoration: none;
}
.admin-menu:hover {
  background-color: #e68900;
}

/* ===== MAIN CONTENT ===== */
.main-content {
  margin-top: 80px;  /* Space below header */
  margin-left: 150px; /* Exactly the width of the left menu */
  padding: 1rem;
  min-height: 100vh; /* Ensure main content extends full height */
  background-color: #fff;
}

/* ===== FLASH MESSAGES ===== */
.alert {
  margin-top: 1rem;
}

/* ===== RESPONSIVE STYLES ===== */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .header-container {
    height: 60px;
  }
  .header-title {
    line-height: 60px;
    font-size: 1.5rem;
  }
  .left-menu {
    top: 60px;
    width: 120px;
  }
  .main-content {
    margin-top: 60px;
    margin-left: 120px;
  }
}

Final Steps

  1. Clear Your Browser Cache:
    Perform a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R or Cmd+Shift+R) to ensure your browser loads the newest CSS and template updates.

  2. Test Your Workflow:

    • Log in as an admin (a user with role="admin").

    • Click on the Admin link in the left-hand menu to see the dashboard.

    • In the Users tab, click Add Player for a user; that user should then appear in the Participants tab with the same table layout.

    • The Remove Player and Freeze Player buttons will update the participant status or flash a message accordingly.

This complete set of code should provide you with an admin dashboard that has two tabs and the requested functionality. Let me know if you need further adjustments or have any questions!

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ sqlalchemy.exc.OperationalError: (sqlite3.OperationalError) no such column: user.participant [SQL: SELECT user.id AS user_id, user.first_name AS user_first_name, user.last_name AS user_last_name, user.username AS user_username, user.password AS user_password, user.email AS user_email, user.phone AS user_phone, user.birth_year AS user_birth_year, user.handedness AS user_handedness, user.role AS user_role, user.participant AS user_participant FROM user WHERE user.username = ? AND user.password = ? LIMIT ?
