␀+/TomislavMarkactomislav.markacadmintmarkac@gmail.com098726316�rightadmin␀␀␀�␀��␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀%leons.markac+ tomislav.markac␀␀␀�␀��␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀
ChatGPT said:

The table in the Users tab is populated from the list of User objects that you query in your admin dashboard route. For example, in your app.py you may have a route like this:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.all()
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

Here, the variable users—created by User.query.all()—contains all the rows from the user table in your database. In your admin.html template, you use a for loop (e.g., {% for user in users %}) to render each row.

Where Is the Database Structure Defined?

The structure of your database is defined by your SQLAlchemy model. For example, your User model might look like this:

python
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')
    participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False)

Each attribute (a db.Column) becomes a column in the user table of your database (stored in your users.db file).

How to Inspect the Database Schema

Since the sqlite3 command isn’t available on your system, here are two alternatives:

1. Use a Graphical SQLite Browser

Download and install DB Browser for SQLite (or a similar tool). Then open your users.db file with it. You’ll be able to inspect:

  • Tables (like the user table)

  • Columns and their data types

  • Any constraints (like UNIQUE or NOT NULL) defined in your model

2. Use a Python Script

You can write a small Python script to inspect the database schema using Python’s built-in sqlite3 module. For example, save the code below as inspect_db.py in your project’s root and run it with python inspect_db.py:

python
import sqlite3

# Connect to the SQLite database file
conn = sqlite3.connect("users.db")
cursor = conn.cursor()

# Get the structure of the 'user' table
cursor.execute("PRAGMA table_info(user);")
columns = cursor.fetchall()

# Print each column's info: (cid, name, type, notnull, dflt_value, pk)
print("User table structure:")
for col in columns:
    print(col)

conn.close()

This script will output a list of tuples, where each tuple represents a column in the user table. For example, you might see output like:

python
(0, 'id', 'INTEGER', 0, None, 1)
(1, 'first_name', 'VARCHAR(80)', 1, None, 0)
(2, 'last_name', 'VARCHAR(80)', 1, None, 0)
(3, 'username', 'VARCHAR(80)', 1, None, 0)
(4, 'password', 'VARCHAR(120)', 1, None, 0)
(5, 'email', 'VARCHAR(120)', 1, None, 0)
(6, 'phone', 'VARCHAR(20)', 1, None, 0)
(7, 'birth_year', 'INTEGER', 1, None, 0)
(8, 'handedness', 'VARCHAR(10)', 1, None, 0)
(9, 'role', 'VARCHAR(20)', 1, 'user', 0)
(10, 'participant', 'BOOLEAN', 1, '0', 0)

This confirms that your table includes the new participant column.

Summary

  • Data Source: The Users tab pulls its data from the users variable, populated by querying User.query.all() in your admin dashboard route.

  • Database Structure: Your SQLAlchemy User model defines the structure of the user table.

  • Inspecting the Structure: You can either use a GUI tool like DB Browser for SQLite or run a Python script (using the sqlite3 module) to query the schema.

Let me know if you need any further help or clarification!

You said:
so this table should have the information which users are participants?
ChatGPT said:

Yes, exactly—the table in the Participants (or Players) tab should display only those users that have been marked as participants (i.e. users for which the participant field is set to True). In our admin dashboard route, we query for these users with something like:

python
participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()

Then in the template for the Participants tab, we loop over this list to display the relevant info (such as name, birth year, etc.). This way, you can differentiate between all users (in the Users tab) and only the participants (in the Players tab).

If you have any further questions, feel free to ask!

You said:
then how come when I click on¸Add player in the User tab it doesn't get acknowledged in the Players tab
ChatGPT said:

Below is an explanation of common causes and steps to troubleshoot why the Players tab isn’t reflecting the change when you click "Add Player" in the Users tab:

Common Causes

  1. Route Not Updating the Database:
    Ensure that your add_participant route is correctly marking the user as a participant and committing the change. For example, the route should look like this:

    python
    @app.route('/add-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def add_participant(user_id):
    user = User.query.get(user_id)
    if user:
        user.participant = True
        db.session.commit()
        flash(f'{user.first_name} {user.last_name} has been added as a participant.', 'success')
    else:
        flash('User not found.', 'danger')
    return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

    Check that:

    • The user object is retrieved successfully.

    • The line db.session.commit() is executed so the change is saved.

  2. Admin Dashboard Query:
    In your admin dashboard route, you must query for participants correctly:

    python
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()

    Then pass that to the template:

    python
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

    Verify that this query returns the expected list. Sometimes, if you’re testing in the same session without clearing the cache or refreshing, you might not see the update immediately.

  3. Caching or Session Issues:
    If you’re using your browser’s cache or have an open session, make sure to do a hard refresh or reopen your admin dashboard page to see the latest data.

  4. Database Schema Updated?
    Double-check that your participant column exists in the database (using a tool like an SQLite browser or a Python script). If it doesn’t, the update won’t work as intended.

Troubleshooting Steps

  1. Check the Flash Message:
    After clicking "Add Player," you should see a flash message indicating that the player was added. This confirms the route was triggered.

  2. Verify the Database:
    Use a Python shell (or a SQLite browser) to query for the user after clicking "Add Player":

    python
    from app import db, User, app
app.app_context().push()
user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
print(user.participant)  # Should print True if updated

    If this still prints False (or raises an error), then the update isn’t taking place.

  3. Inspect the Admin Dashboard:
    Ensure that your admin dashboard route is re-querying the database and passing the updated list to the template:

    python
    @app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.all()
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

    Each time you refresh this page, the updated participant list should be shown.

  4. Restart the Application:
    Sometimes changes to the database or code might not reflect until you restart your Flask server.

Summary

  • Verify the Implementation of add_participant: Make sure it correctly updates and commits the participant status.

  • Ensure the Admin Dashboard Refreshes the Query: The route must pass a fresh list of participants (with participant=True) to the template.

  • Clear Browser/Server Cache: Hard refresh your page and restart your app if needed.

These checks should help you determine why the Players tab isn’t reflecting added participants. Let me know if you need further assistance!

You said:
>>> participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all() Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> NameError: name 'User' is not defined
ChatGPT said:

Make sure you import the User model (along with db and app) before running the query. In your Python shell, try the following:

python
from app import User, db, app
app.app_context().push()
participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()
print(participants)

This ensures that User is defined in your shell’s namespace and that you are within an application context so that SQLAlchemy queries work properly.

You said:
File "C:\Users\tmarkac\Python_projects\Tennis_app\venv\Lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\sql\base.py", line 2181, in _entity_namespace_key return getattr(ns, key) # type: ignore ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ AttributeError: type object 'User' has no attribute 'participant' The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception: Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> File "C:\Users\tmarkac\Python_projects\Tennis_app\venv\Lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\orm\query.py", line 1991, in filter_by clauses = [ ^ File "C:\Users\tmarkac\Python_projects\Tennis_app\venv\Lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\orm\query.py", line 1992, in <listcomp> _entity_namespace_key(from_entity, key) == value ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ File "C:\Users\tmarkac\Python_projects\Tennis_app\venv\Lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\sql\base.py", line 2183, in _entity_namespace_key raise exc.InvalidRequestError( sqlalchemy.exc.InvalidRequestError: Entity namespace for "user" has no property "participant" >>> print(participants) Traceback (most recent call last): File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> NameError: name 'participants' is not defined
ChatGPT said:

The error:

vbnet
sqlalchemy.exc.InvalidRequestError: Entity namespace for "user" has no property "participant"

indicates that SQLAlchemy doesn’t see a participant property on your User model. This usually happens if the model wasn’t updated or reloaded after you added the new column. Here are some steps to resolve the issue:

1. Verify Your Model Code

Make sure your User model in your app.py (or wherever you define it) includes the following line:

python
participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False)

Your model should look similar to this:

python
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')
    participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False)

    def __repr__(self):
        return f'<User {self.username}>'

2. Check Which Version Is Being Imported

If you recently updated the model, ensure that the file you’re importing is actually saved and being used. Sometimes an unsaved file or caching in your interactive shell (or your IDE) can cause you to use an older version of the model.

Try running:

python
from app import User
print(User.__table__)

Look in the printed metadata to see if the participant column is listed. If it isn’t, that means your model code isn’t being loaded as expected.

3. Update Your Database Schema

Even if your model code now includes the participant column, if you already created your database (e.g., users.db) before you added it, the new column won’t exist in the database schema. However, note that the error you're seeing is happening at the ORM model metadata level (not when executing a SQL statement) which means SQLAlchemy thinks the model itself doesn’t have a participant attribute.

If you haven't yet updated the model in your file, you'll need to do so. If you have updated it, then:

  • For development (quick fix):
    Stop your Flask application, delete the users.db file, and restart the app. The db.create_all() call should recreate a new database with the updated schema, and the model metadata will include participant.

  • For production:
    Use a migration tool such as Flask-Migrate so that you can apply the schema change without deleting your existing data.

4. Restart Your Python Shell / Server

After saving changes to your model:

  • Restart your Flask server.

  • If you’re running commands in an interactive Python shell, exit and restart the shell so that it reloads the updated code.

Summary

  • Update your model code to include the participant column.

  • Verify with print(User.__table__) that the column shows up in the model’s metadata.

  • Delete your existing database file (or run a migration) if necessary.

  • Restart your environment to pick up the changes.

Once your model is updated and your database is refreshed, running:

python
from app import User, db, app
app.app_context().push()
participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()
print(participants)

should now work without error and show you a list of users (even if it might be empty by default).

Let me know if you need any further help or clarification!

You said:
>>> participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False) >>> nothing is happpening when I do this
ChatGPT said:

The line you typed:

python
participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False)

by itself in the Python shell doesn’t update the existing User model or the database. You need to do the following:

  1. Add it in Your Model:
    Open your project file where your User model is defined (typically in app.py or a separate models file) and ensure your User model now looks like this (or includes the new field):

    python
    class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    first_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    last_name = db.Column(db.String(80), nullable=False)
    username = db.Column(db.String(80), unique=True, nullable=False)
    password = db.Column(db.String(120), nullable=False)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    phone = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False)
    birth_year = db.Column(db.Integer, nullable=False)
    handedness = db.Column(db.String(10), nullable=False)
    role = db.Column(db.String(20), nullable=False, default='user')
    participant = db.Column(db.Boolean, nullable=False, default=False)

    def __repr__(self):
        return f'<User {self.username}>'

    Make sure you save the file after making these changes.

  2. Update the Database Schema:
    If your database (users.db) was created before you added the participant column, the existing database won’t have that column. For a development environment, you can do one of the following:

    • Delete the Database File:
      Stop your Flask app, delete the users.db file, and restart your Flask application. The call to db.create_all() will now recreate the database with the updated schema.

    • Use Flask-Migrate:
      Set up Flask-Migrate to manage schema changes without deleting existing data. (See instructions from our previous discussion for installation and commands.)

  3. Restart the Application or Python Shell:
    After saving your changes and updating the database schema, restart your Flask app or the interactive Python shell so that it uses the updated model definition.

After completing these steps, running code like:

python
from app import User, db, app
app.app_context().push()
user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
print(user.participant)

should no longer produce an error, and it should show you the default value (False, unless changed) for the participant field.

Let me know if you have any questions or need further assistance!

You can execute arbitrary Python code in the stack frames and there are some extra helpers available for introspection: dump() shows all variables in the frame dump(obj) dumps all that's known about the object Brought to you by DON'T PANIC, your friendly Werkzeug powered traceback interpreter.
ChatGPT said:

The error indicates that your current database schema still does not have the new participant column defined in the User model. Even though you've updated your model code, the old users.db file is still being used. You have two main options:

Option 1: Delete and Recreate the Database (Development)

  1. Stop your Flask application.

  2. Locate and delete the users.db file in your project directory.

  3. Restart your Flask app.
    With the call to db.create_all() in your if __name__ == '__main__': block (or via Flask-Migrate if set up), a new database will be created with the updated schema including the participant column.

  4. Verify the update.
    You can open a Python shell:

    bash
    python

    and run:

    python
    from app import db, User, app
app.app_context().push()
user = User.query.first()
print(user)

    Use a tool like DB Browser for SQLite or a Python script (see below) to inspect the schema:

    python
    import sqlite3
conn = sqlite3.connect("users.db")
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("PRAGMA table_info(user);")
for col in cursor.fetchall():
    print(col)
conn.close()

    Ensure that you see a column called participant in the output.

Option 2: Use Flask-Migrate for Schema Changes

If you want to avoid deleting your database (especially in production), you can use Flask-Migrate to handle schema changes.

  1. Install Flask-Migrate (if you haven’t already):

    bash
    pip install Flask-Migrate

  2. Initialize Flask-Migrate in your app.
    In your app.py, after you create the app and db, add:

    python
    from flask_migrate import Migrate
migrate = Migrate(app, db)

  3. Set the FLASK_APP Environment Variable:
    In your terminal:

    • For Windows PowerShell:

      powershell
      $env:FLASK_APP = "app.py"
$env:FLASK_ENV = "development"

    • For CMD:

      cmd
      set FLASK_APP=app.py
set FLASK_ENV=development

  4. Run the Migration Commands:

    bash
    flask db init
flask db migrate -m "Add participant column"
flask db upgrade

    This will update the database schema while preserving your data.

Summary

The error occurs because the database file users.db was created before you added the participant column to your User model. Therefore, the ORM query User.query.all() tries to select a column that doesn’t exist in the database.

  • Development: The quickest way is to delete users.db and restart your app so that the schema is recreated.

  • Production: Use Flask-Migrate so you can handle schema changes without data loss.

Once you update your schema, your admin dashboard and any queries filtering by participant will work as expected.

Let me know if you need any further assistance!

You said:
>>> import sqlite3 >>> conn = sqlite3.connect("users.db") >>> cursor = conn.cursor() >>> cursor.execute("PRAGMA table_info(user);") <sqlite3.Cursor object at 0x00000266345C9EC0> >>> for col in cursor.fetchall(): ... print(col) ... conn.close() File "<stdin>", line 3 conn.close() ^^^^ SyntaxError: invalid syntax
ChatGPT said:

In the interactive shell you need to ensure that you finish the indented block (by pressing Enter on an empty line) before calling conn.close(). For example, try:

python
for col in cursor.fetchall():
    print(col)

conn.close()

Make sure you press Enter after the loop block to exit the block and then run conn.close() on a new line. This should resolve the syntax error.

You said:
I want to make user tomislav.markac admin
ChatGPT said:

To update the role of user "tomislav.markac" to admin, you need to update the value in the database. Since your database schema now includes a role column (assuming you have updated your model and recreated or migrated your database), you can do this using a Python shell. Follow these steps:

  1. Open Your Terminal in Visual Studio Code
    Make sure your working directory is where your app.py file is located.

  2. Activate Your Virtual Environment (if applicable)
    For example, on Windows:

    bash
    .\venv\Scripts\activate

    or on macOS/Linux:

    bash
    source venv/bin/activate

  3. Start an Interactive Python Shell
    In your terminal, type:

    bash
    python

    and press Enter.

  4. Import Your App, DB, and User Model
    Type (or paste) these lines one by one:

    python
    from app import app, db, User
app.app_context().push()

  5. Query and Update the User
    Now type (or paste) the following code:

    python
    user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
if user is None:
    print("User not found!")
else:
    user.role = "admin"
    db.session.commit()
    print("User role updated to admin.")

  6. Exit the Shell
    After you see the confirmation message, type:

    python
    exit()

    or press Ctrl+D to exit.

  7. Restart Your Application and Log In Again
    This ensures that the session picks up the updated role. Once you log in as "tomislav.markac," the session should show the role as "admin," and any admin-only content will now be visible.

If you encounter any issues (for example, if the database still doesn't have the role column), you may need to delete your existing users.db file (or run a migration with Flask-Migrate) to recreate the schema with the new column.

Let me know if you have any further questions!

You said:
still I dont see any users added to the table on players tab when clicked on Add Player
ChatGPT said:

The behavior you're describing usually means that although the route is being called (you see the flash message), the change is either not being committed to the database or the admin dashboard isn’t re‐querying the updated data.

Here’s a checklist and some troubleshooting steps:

1. Verify the add_participant Route

Make sure that your add_participant route is defined like this in your app.py:

python
@app.route('/add-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def add_participant(user_id):
    user = User.query.get(user_id)
    if user:
        user.participant = True
        db.session.commit()   # This commits the change to the database.
        flash(f'{user.first_name} {user.last_name} has been added as a participant.', 'success')
    else:
        flash('User not found.', 'danger')
    return redirect(url_for('admin_dashboard'))

Check these details:

  • User Retrieval: The function uses User.query.get(user_id) to fetch the user by ID.

  • Database Commit: It calls db.session.commit() to persist the change.

  • Flash Message: It flashes a success message if the update occurs.

2. Check the Admin Dashboard Route

Your admin dashboard route should re-query the database so the template gets an updated list:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.all()
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).all()  # Query for participants
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

Each time the admin dashboard is loaded, it should rebuild the list of participants based on the current state of the database.

3. Inspect the Database

After clicking "Add Player", verify in an interactive Python shell that the user’s participant attribute is set to True:

  1. Open your terminal in VS Code.

  2. Activate your virtual environment and start a Python shell:

    bash
    python

  3. In the shell, run:

    python
    from app import db, User, app
app.app_context().push()
user = User.query.filter_by(username="tomislav.markac").first()
print(user.participant)

    If it prints True, then the update is working but your template might not be reloading the data as expected. If it still prints False, then the update isn’t happening.

4. Ensure the Database Schema is Updated

If your database was created before you added the participant column, that column won’t exist—even if your model is updated. To resolve this:

  • Delete the DB File: For development, delete the users.db file (after stopping the server) and restart your app so db.create_all() creates the updated schema.

  • Or Use Migrations: Use Flask-Migrate to update your schema without losing data.

5. Check for Browser Cache Issues

After making changes, do a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R on Windows or Cmd+Shift+R on macOS) to ensure your browser isn’t showing cached data.

Final Verification

Your admin dashboard (admin.html) template should loop over the participants variable. For example, the Players tab might include:

html
<div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
  <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
    <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
      <thead>
        <tr>
          <th>Player Name</th>
          <th>Year of Birth</th>
          <th>Total Matches</th>
          <th>Win</th>
          <th>Loss</th>
          <th>Win %</th>
          <th>Actions</th>
        </tr>
      </thead>
      <tbody>
        {% for participant in participants %}
        <tr>
          <td>
            <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=participant.username) }}">
              {{ participant.first_name }} {{ participant.last_name }}
            </a>
          </td>
          <td>{{ participant.birth_year }}</td>
          <td>0</td>
          <td>0</td>
          <td>0</td>
          <td>0%</td>
          <td>
            <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
            <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
          </td>
        </tr>
        {% else %}
        <tr>
          <td colspan="7" class="text-center">No participants added yet.</td>
        </tr>
        {% endfor %}
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </div>
</div>

If after checking all the above you still don’t see the updated participant in the Players tab, try:

  • Reloading the page after a short delay.

  • Checking the flash message to ensure the add_participant route is reached.

  • Verifying your development database contains the updated user record.

Following these troubleshooting steps should help you determine why the Players tab isn’t reflecting the added participants. Let me know if you have any further questions or need additional help!

Did you mean 'remove_participant' instead? The debugger caught an exception in your WSGI application. You can now look at the traceback which led to the error. To switch between the interactive traceback and the plaintext one, you can click on the "Traceback" headline. From the text traceback you can also create a paste of it. For code execution mouse-over the frame you want to debug and click on the console icon on the right side. You can execute arbitrary Python code in the stack frames and there are some extra helpers available for introspection: dump() shows all variables in the frame dump(obj) dumps all that's known about the object Brought to you by DON'T PANIC, your friendly Werkzeug powered traceback interpreter.
ChatGPT said:

You received this error because Flask couldn’t find a route named "freeze_participant". In other words, you have a link in your template calling:

html
<a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>

but you don’t have a corresponding route in your app.py for freeze_participant.

If you don’t want to implement the functionality right now (and instead show a flash message and then redirect), you can add a dummy route for it. Here’s how you do it:

Step 1: Add a Dummy Freeze Participant Route in app.py

Add the following code to your app.py (ensure it’s placed in the global scope along with your other participant routes):

python
@app.route('/freeze-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def freeze_participant(user_id):
    flash("Freeze participant functionality is not implemented yet.", "info")
    return redirect(url_for("admin_dashboard"))

This route will ensure that when your template calls url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id), Flask can build the URL and, upon clicking, it will display a flash message and redirect back to your admin dashboard.

Step 2: Restart Your Flask Application

After adding the above code, save app.py and restart your Flask application so that the changes take effect. This should allow the freeze button to work without raising a BuildError.

Summary

  • The BuildError occurred because the freeze_participant endpoint wasn’t defined.

  • By adding the dummy route shown above, you instruct Flask how to handle URLs to /freeze-participant/<user_id>.

  • Restart your app to pick up the new route, then clicking the Freeze Player button should now flash the message and redirect without error.

Let me know if you need further assistance!

You said:
Lets make a method for remove player button in players tab. When clicked it should delete that players entry in the table in players tab and change the participant true value to false in appropriate database
ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete implementation of a "Remove Player" route for your admin dashboard. When the admin clicks the Remove Player button in the Players tab, this route will:

  • Find the user by ID.

  • Set their participant flag to False (which removes them from the Players tab since that tab only shows users with participant=True).

  • Commit the change to the database.

  • Flash a success (or error) message.

  • Redirect back to the admin dashboard.

You can add this route to your existing app.py file (make sure it’s placed in the global scope with your other routes):

python
@app.route('/remove-participant/<int:user_id>')
@admin_required
def remove_participant(user_id):
    user = User.query.get(user_id)
    if user:
        if user.participant:
            user.participant = False
            db.session.commit()
            flash(f"{user.first_name} {user.last_name} has been removed from participants.", "success")
        else:
            flash("User is not a participant.", "warning")
    else:
        flash("User not found.", "danger")
    return redirect(url_for("admin_dashboard"))

How This Works

  • Query the User:
    User.query.get(user_id) retrieves the user with the given ID.

  • Check and Update:
    We check if the user exists and if their participant flag is currently True. If so, we set it to False and commit the change.

  • Flash Messages:
    A success message is flashed if the update is successful. If the user isn’t marked as a participant, we flash a warning instead. If no user is found, an error message is shown.

  • Redirect:
    The admin is redirected back to the admin dashboard so that the Players tab is updated on reload.

Once this route is added, clicking the Remove Player button (which calls url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) in your template) will update the database, and on reloading the dashboard the removed user will no longer be listed in the Players tab.

Make sure you restart your Flask server after modifying your app.py. If any caching issues arise, do a hard refresh in your browser.

Let me know if you need further assistance!

You said:
I want both tables to be sorted alphabetically and change the column name in Users tab to Username instead of player name.
ChatGPT said:

Below is an updated example that sorts both tables alphabetically by username and changes the column header in the Users tab from "Player Name" to "Username." Follow these steps:

Update the Admin Dashboard Route in app.py

In your admin dashboard route, update the queries to order the results alphabetically by username:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.order_by(User.username).all()       # Sorted alphabetically
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).order_by(User.username).all()  # Sorted alphabetically
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

Update the admin.html Template

In your templates/admin.html, change the header in the Users tab and update the corresponding cell values to display the username. The Players tab remains as before (or you can apply similar changes if desired).

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5">
  <h2>Admin Dashboard</h2>

  <!-- Bootstrap Tabs -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">
        Users
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="participants-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#participants" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="participants" aria-selected="false">
        Players
      </button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Username</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.username }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('add_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</a>
                {% else %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                {% endif %}
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>

    <!-- Players Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for participant in participants %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=participant.username) }}">
                  {{ participant.first_name }} {{ participant.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ participant.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% else %}
            <tr>
              <td colspan="7" class="text-center">No participants added yet.</td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

Summary

  • Query Updates: Both queries in the admin dashboard route are now sorted alphabetically by User.username using the SQLAlchemy order_by() method.

  • Template Changes:
    In the Users tab, the header is changed to "Username" and each row now displays user.username (linked to the profile page) instead of concatenated first name and last name. The Players tab remains as before (using the first name and last name display) but is also sorted alphabetically if you choose the same ordering in your route queries.

Copy and paste the updated code into your project. Make sure you save your files and restart your Flask application (or do a hard refresh if already running) so that the changes take effect. Let me know if you have any further questions!

You said:
tables are not sorted alphabetically but it did change the column header
ChatGPT said:

Make sure your admin dashboard route is updated to retrieve users sorted by username. For example, your route should look like this:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    # Query all users, sorted alphabetically by username
    all_users = User.query.order_by(User.username).all()
    # Query only participants, also sorted by username
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).order_by(User.username).all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

If you already have this code and still don't see the tables sorted alphabetically, try these steps:

  1. Confirm Data:
    Verify that the username field is properly populated for your users (e.g., "tomislav.markac" would be sorted with other usernames). If your usernames are not consistent or are empty, sorting might seem off.

  2. Restart the Server:
    Save your changes and restart your Flask server to ensure the updated route is used. Sometimes running in debug mode or a cached instance might not pick up the new queries.

  3. Hard Refresh the Browser:
    Clear the browser cache or do a hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R on Windows or Cmd+Shift+R on macOS) so that you see the updated data.

  4. Double-Check the Query:
    If you’re testing in a Python shell, you can run:

    python
    from app import User, app
app.app_context().push()
users = User.query.order_by(User.username).all()
for user in users:
    print(user.username)

    This will print out the usernames in sorted order. If they are sorted in the console but not in the rendered table, it’s likely a template issue. Otherwise, the query might not be using the updated code.

After confirming these points, your tables should be sorted alphabetically by the username. Let me know if you need further assistance!

You said:
create Back to landing page button for in top right corner of the admin-dashboard which should return the admin back to landing page
ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete updated version of your admin.html that includes a "Back to Landing Page" button in the top right corner of the admin dashboard. This button links back to your landing page. Additionally, the dashboard is organized into two tabs—"Users" and "Players"—with the Users tab showing a table of all users and the Players tab (for now) showing the table of participants.

Copy and paste the following code into your templates/admin.html file:

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5 position-relative">
  <!-- Back to Landing Page Button (top right) -->
  <div class="position-absolute" style="top: 0; right: 0;">
    <a href="{{ url_for('home') }}" class="btn btn-secondary">Back to Landing Page</a>
  </div>
  
  <h2>Admin Dashboard</h2>
  
  <!-- Bootstrap Tabs -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">
        Users
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="participants-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#participants" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="participants" aria-selected="false">
        Players
      </button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Username</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.username }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('add_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</a>
                {% else %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                {% endif %}
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <!-- Players Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for participant in participants %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=participant.username) }}">
                  {{ participant.first_name }} {{ participant.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ participant.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% else %}
            <tr>
              <td colspan="7" class="text-center">No participants added yet.</td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

How This Works

  • Back Button:
    A <div> with position-absolute is placed inside the container, aligned to the top right with inline CSS. This button uses Bootstrap styling and links to your landing page via url_for('home').

  • Tabs:
    Two tabs are implemented using Bootstrap's nav-tabs:

    • Users Tab: Displays a table of all registered users (with the "Username" header).

    • Players Tab: Displays a table of participants. (You can later add and remove players to update this table.)

  • Data Population:
    Your admin dashboard route should pass two lists (users and participants) to this template, sorted alphabetically if desired.
    For instance:

    python
    @app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.order_by(User.username).all()
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).order_by(User.username).all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

Once you've added this file, save it, clear your cache/hard refresh if needed, and test the "Back to Landing Page" button along with the two tabs functionality in your admin dashboard.

Let me know if you need further modifications or any help!

You said:
TemplateSyntaxError jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError: Unexpected end of template. Jinja was looking for the following tags: 'endblock'. The innermost block that needs to be closed is 'block'. You can now look at the traceback which led to the error. To switch between the interactive traceback and the plaintext one, you can click on the "Traceback" headline. From the text traceback you can also create a paste of it. For code execution mouse-over the frame you want to debug and click on the console icon on the right side. You can execute arbitrary Python code in the stack frames and there are some extra helpers available for introspection: dump() shows all variables in the frame dump(obj) dumps all that's known about the object Brought to you by DON'T PANIC, your friendly Werkzeug powered traceback interpreter.
ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete, revised version of your admin.html template that includes two tabs ("Users" and "Players") along with a "Back to Landing Page" button in the top right corner. This version ensures that all Jinja2 blocks are properly closed.

Copy and paste the following into your templates/admin.html file:

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5 position-relative">
  <!-- Back to Landing Page Button (top right) -->
  <div class="position-absolute" style="top: 0; right: 0;">
    <a href="{{ url_for('home') }}" class="btn btn-secondary">Back to Landing Page</a>
  </div>
  <h2>Admin Dashboard</h2>
  
  <!-- Bootstrap Tabs -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">
        Users
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="participants-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#participants" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="participants" aria-selected="false">
        Players
      </button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Username</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.username }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('add_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</a>
                {% else %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                {% endif %}
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <!-- Players Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for participant in participants %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=participant.username) }}">
                  {{ participant.first_name }} {{ participant.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ participant.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% else %}
            <tr>
              <td colspan="7" class="text-center">No participants added yet.</td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

Explanation

  • Back Button:
    A "Back to Landing Page" button is added in a div with position-absolute at the top right, linking to your landing page via url_for('home').

  • Tabs:
    Two tabs are created using Bootstrap's nav-tabs—one for "Users" and one for "Players."

    • In the Users tab, the table header has been updated to "Username" and it lists all users using the users variable.

    • In the Players tab, the table displays participants using the participants variable.

  • Block Endings:
    All {% block %} tags are properly closed with {% endblock %}.

Make sure your admin dashboard route in app.py passes both users and participants lists to this template and that you have the appropriate participant management routes (even if they are dummy routes) so that the URL calls resolve without error.

Let me know if you need further adjustments!

You said:
in the admin dashboard create new tab called Groups
ChatGPT said:

Below is an updated version of your admin.html template that now includes three tabs: "Users", "Players", and a new "Groups" tab. In this example, the Groups tab contains placeholder text that you can later update with your desired functionality.

Copy and paste the entire updated code into your templates/admin.html file:

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5 position-relative">
  <!-- Back to Landing Page Button (top right) -->
  <div class="position-absolute" style="top: 0; right: 0;">
    <a href="{{ url_for('home') }}" class="btn btn-secondary">Back to Landing Page</a>
  </div>
  
  <h2>Admin Dashboard</h2>
  
  <!-- Bootstrap Tabs -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">
        Users
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="participants-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#participants" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="participants" aria-selected="false">
        Players
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="groups-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#groups" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="groups" aria-selected="false">
        Groups
      </button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Username</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.username }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('add_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</a>
                {% else %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                {% endif %}
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <!-- Players Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for participant in participants %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=participant.username) }}">
                  {{ participant.first_name }} {{ participant.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ participant.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% else %}
            <tr>
              <td colspan="7" class="text-center">No participants added yet.</td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <!-- Groups Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="groups" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="groups-tab">
      <div class="mt-3">
        <p>Groups functionality is under development. This tab will eventually contain the list of groups for the tournament.</p>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>
{% endblock %}

How It Works

  1. Tabs Implementation:

    • The <ul class="nav nav-tabs"> creates three tabs: Users, Players, and Groups.

    • Each tab is defined by a <button> with a data-bs-target that matches the ID of the corresponding content pane.

  2. Content Panes:

    • The Users tab displays a table of all users (with the header "Username" instead of "Player Name").

    • The Players tab displays a table for participants filtered by the participant flag.

    • The Groups tab contains placeholder text that you can later replace with your actual groups functionality.

  3. Back Button:

    • A "Back to Landing Page" button is located at the top right (using absolute positioning) so that the admin can quickly return to the landing page.

Make sure that your admin dashboard route in app.py passes both users and participants variables when rendering this template. For example:

python
@app.route('/admin-dashboard')
@admin_required
def admin_dashboard():
    all_users = User.query.order_by(User.username).all()
    participants = User.query.filter_by(participant=True).order_by(User.username).all()
    return render_template('admin.html', users=all_users, participants=participants)

This updated template should give you three tabs in your admin dashboard. Let me know if you need any further modifications or assistance!

When clicked a form or pop up with the form should appear with following fields: - Competiton name(text) -Number of Groups(positive integer) -Maximum number of players in one group: (positive integer= and the Submit button that should remember this inputs as they will be used later. Then if Admin entered i.e. 6 groups and 5 players, 6 tables should be created in the Create Competition tab one below the other. Above them should be competition name and title of each table should be Group A, B, C, D, E, F, G as Admin selected 6 groups. Can you give me the entire code for this so I can copy/paste

ChatGPT said:
You said:

ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete version of your updated admin dashboard template (admin.html). In this template, we have three tabs:

  • Users: (same as before, with a table of all users)

  • Players: (listing only participants)

  • Create Competition: This new tab displays the total number of players (using the length of the participants list passed from the route) and a "Create Competition" button. When clicked, a Bootstrap modal appears containing a form with the following fields:

    • Competition name (text)

    • Number of Groups (positive integer)

    • Maximum Number of Players in One Group (positive integer)

When the admin submits this form, the modal hides and (for demo purposes) JavaScript generates N (number of groups) tables below that tab, with the competition name displayed at the top and each table titled with group names “Group A”, “Group B”, etc.

You’ll need to ensure that your admin dashboard route in your app.py passes two variables:

  • users: all users sorted (as before)

  • participants: the list of participants (for which participant == True)

Below is the complete code for admin.html. (You can later modify or persist these competition details as needed.)

templates/admin.html

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5 position-relative">
  <!-- Back to Landing Page Button (top right) -->
  <div class="position-absolute" style="top: 0; right: 0;">
    <a href="{{ url_for('home') }}" class="btn btn-secondary">Back to Landing Page</a>
  </div>
  
  <h2 class="mt-3">Admin Dashboard</h2>
  
  <!-- Bootstrap Tabs -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">
        Users
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="participants-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#participants" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="participants" aria-selected="false">
        Players
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="competition-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#competition" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="competition" aria-selected="false">
        Create Competition
      </button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Username</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.username }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('add_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-success btn-sm">Add Player</a>
                {% else %}
                  <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                {% endif %}
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=user.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <!-- Players Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="participants" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="participants-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player Name</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for participant in participants %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=participant.username) }}">
                  {{ participant.first_name }} {{ participant.last_name }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ participant.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('remove_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-warning btn-sm">Remove Player</a>
                <a href="{{ url_for('freeze_participant', user_id=participant.id) }}" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm">Freeze Player</a>
              </td>
            </tr>
            {% else %}
            <tr>
              <td colspan="7" class="text-center">No participants added yet.</td>
            </tr>
            {% endfor %}
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    </div>
    
    <!-- Create Competition Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade" id="competition" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="competition-tab">
      <div class="mt-3">
        <p>Total number of players: <strong>{{ participants|length }}</strong></p>
        <button class="btn btn-primary" data-bs-toggle="modal" data-bs-target="#competitionModal">Create Competition</button>
      </div>
      
      <!-- Placeholder for generated group tables after competition creation -->
      <div id="competitionResult" class="mt-4"></div>
      
      <!-- Bootstrap Modal for Competition Creation Form -->
      <div class="modal fade" id="competitionModal" tabindex="-1" aria-labelledby="competitionModalLabel" aria-hidden="true">
        <div class="modal-dialog">
          <div class="modal-content">
            <form id="competitionForm">
              <div class="modal-header">
                <h5 class="modal-title" id="competitionModalLabel">Create Competition</h5>
                <button type="button" class="btn-close" data-bs-dismiss="modal" aria-label="Close"></button>
              </div>
              <div class="modal-body">
                <div class="mb-3">
                  <label for="compName" class="form-label">Competition Name</label>
                  <input type="text" class="form-control" id="compName" name="compName" required>
                </div>
                <div class="mb-3">
                  <label for="numGroups" class="form-label">Number of Groups</label>
                  <input type="number" class="form-control" id="numGroups" name="numGroups" min="1" required>
                </div>
                <div class="mb-3">
                  <label for="maxPlayers" class="form-label">Maximum Number of Players in One Group</label>
                  <input type="number" class="form-control" id="maxPlayers" name="maxPlayers" min="1" required>
                </div>
              </div>
              <div class="modal-footer">
                <button type="button" class="btn btn-secondary" data-bs-dismiss="modal">Cancel</button>
                <button type="submit" class="btn btn-primary">Submit</button>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div> <!-- End Create Competition Tab -->
  </div>
</div>

<!-- JavaScript to Process the Competition Form -->
<script>
document.getElementById("competitionForm").addEventListener("submit", function(e) {
  e.preventDefault();
  // Get form values
  const compName = document.getElementById("compName").value;
  const numGroups = parseInt(document.getElementById("numGroups").value, 10);
  const maxPlayers = parseInt(document.getElementById("maxPlayers").value, 10);

  // Close the modal (using Bootstrap 5 modal methods)
  var competitionModalEl = document.getElementById('competitionModal');
  var modal = bootstrap.Modal.getInstance(competitionModalEl);
  modal.hide();

  // Display competition name and create tables for each group
  let resultHtml = `<h3>Competition: ${compName}</h3>`;
  const groupLetters = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ";
  for(let i = 0; i < numGroups; i++){
    const groupName = `Group ${groupLetters[i] || i+1}`;
    resultHtml += `
      <div class="mt-3">
        <h5>${groupName}</h5>
        <table class="table table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Player</th>
              <th>Score</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            <!-- This is where players for ${groupName} will be assigned -->
            <tr>
              <td colspan="2" class="text-center">No players assigned yet.</td>
            </tr>
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    `;
  }
  document.getElementById("competitionResult").innerHTML = resultHtml;
});
</script>
{% endblock %}

Explanation

  1. New Tab “Create Competition”:

    • The tab shows the total number of players (by outputting {{ participants|length }}) and a "Create Competition" button.

  2. Bootstrap Modal:

    • A modal form is triggered when the button is clicked. The form asks for the Competition Name, Number of Groups, and Maximum Number of Players in One Group.

  3. JavaScript Form Handling:

    • When the modal form is submitted, an event listener prevents the default form submission.

    • It reads the inputs and then hides the modal.

    • It dynamically generates the competition output: the competition name and (based on the number of groups) multiple tables labeled with group names (using "Group A", "Group B", etc.). For now, each table contains a placeholder row stating "No players assigned yet."

  4. Integration:

    • This code assumes that your admin dashboard route passes both users and participants from the database. If not, you will need to update that route accordingly.

    • You can later extend the functionality to assign players to groups based on the maximum number of players specified.

Save this updated template as admin.html in your templates folder, then restart your Flask app and test the new "Create Competition" tab functionality.

Let me know if you need any further changes or additional details!

You said:
Gret buts lets change something. Can adjsut the code so it puts each competition in a separate tab as Admin might crate more than one competition. Each tab should be named by its competition name
ChatGPT said:

Below is a complete updated version of your admin dashboard template (admin.html). In this version, we’ve added a new tab—"Create Competition"—that shows:

  • The total number of players (pulled from the participants list).

  • A "Create Competition" button that opens a Bootstrap modal.

When the admin submits the modal form, a new competition tab is created dynamically (each tab is labeled with the competition name). The corresponding content displays a series of tables—one table per group—each titled "Group A", "Group B", etc., based on the number of groups entered.

For demonstration purposes, the competition data is handled only on the client side (i.e. it’s not stored in your database). You can later extend the solution to persist competition details as needed.

Please copy and paste the code below into your templates/admin.html file:

html
{% extends "base.html" %}
{% block title %}Admin Dashboard{% endblock %}
{% block content %}
<div class="container mt-5 position-relative">
  <!-- Back to Landing Page Button (top right) -->
  <div class="position-absolute" style="top: 0; right: 0;">
    <a href="{{ url_for('home') }}" class="btn btn-secondary">Back to Landing Page</a>
  </div>
  
  <h2 class="mt-3">Admin Dashboard</h2>

  <!-- Primary Tabs: Users, Players, Create Competition -->
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs" id="adminTab" role="tablist">
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link active" id="users-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#users" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="users" aria-selected="true">
        Users
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="players-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#players" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="players" aria-selected="false">
        Players
      </button>
    </li>
    <li class="nav-item" role="presentation">
      <button class="nav-link" id="competition-tab" data-bs-toggle="tab" data-bs-target="#competition" type="button" role="tab" aria-controls="competition" aria-selected="false">
        Create Competition
      </button>
    </li>
  </ul>
  
  <div class="tab-content" id="adminTabContent">
    <!-- Users Tab -->
    <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="users" role="tabpanel" aria-labelledby="users-tab">
      <div class="table-responsive mt-3">
        <table class="table table-striped table-bordered">
          <thead>
            <tr>
              <th>Username</th>
              <th>Year of Birth</th>
              <th>Total Matches</th>
              <th>Win</th>
              <th>Loss</th>
              <th>Win %</th>
              <th>Actions</th>
            </tr>
          </thead>
          <tbody>
            {% for user in users %}
            <tr>
              <td>
                <a href="{{ url_for('profile_by_username', username=user.username) }}">
                  {{ user.username }}
                </a>
              </td>
              <td>{{ user.birth_year }}</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0</td>
              <td>0%</td>
              <td>
                {% if not user.participant %}
